"The Pragmatic Programmer" by A. Hunt & D. Thomas
Book review

01 November 2015
This post is part of a series of book reviews and is a way to quickly share my opinion on what I've been reading, not a general analysis of the book. If "The Pragmatic Programmer" by A. Hunt & D. Thomas feels like something you'd like to read, you can grab a copy here.

This is one of the books I’ve heard referenced countless times by very smart people before I actually got to read it. Expectations were high, but Andrew Hunt and David Thomas delivered. This book dives into everything that a modern developer needs to aprehend in order to create good software and stay up to date.

I now find myself quoting it constantly when coaching teams or teaching junior developers.

"You can't write perfect software" pic.twitter.com/AbMbNLA7du

— Marc G Gauthier (@marcgg) January 5, 2015

The book is filled with situations that every professional developers encounter in their lives: estimations requests, “programming by coincidence”, how to do design by contract or what tools to use. It also describes some best practices such as “crash early” or ways to minimize coupling.

FFS Fred, seriously. I thought you knew better. pic.twitter.com/oMJv7zZRRy

— Marc G Gauthier (@marcgg) January 5, 2015

This book is one of my references, and I can’t recommend it enough. If you haven’t read it yet, you should!

Since you scrolled this far, you might as well take a look at some other things I wrote !

  • "The Clean Coder" by Robert C. Martin
  • "Work Rules!" by Laszlo Bock

Get the book: "The Pragmatic Programmer" by A. Hunt & D. Thomas
